title: Man 'who threw his son to his death from a bridge over a river in Manchester' is sectioned
text:
Zak Eko (pictured above) has been moved from prison to a secure hospital

A man who 'threw his 11-month-old son to death from a bridge' has been sectioned under the Mental Health Act.

Zak Eko is awaiting trial after being charged with murdering his son Zakari William Bennett-Eko in Manchester in September.

The baby boy was found in the River Irwell near a bridge in Radcliffe, on September 11.

Zakari was retrieved from the water and taken to hospital but he later died.

His father, 22, has been moved from Forest Bank prison in Salford to a secure hospital while he awaits a murder trial.

Eko had been arrested shortly after the incident and charged with murder.

He has since made two court appearances, the last one at Manchester Crown Court on September 16.

The defendant was not asked to enter pleas on the murder charge nor on an alternative charge of manslaughter.

After his death, tributes poured in for Zakari (above) with some saying he had been an 'innocent little boy'

Appearing via videolink from Forest Bank prison, he was remanded in custody and is due to reappear at Manchester Crown Court on December 20 for a plea and directions hearing.

A trial date had been fixed for March 9.

A spokesperson for Greater Manchester Police has since confirmed Mr Eko has been sectioned under the Mental Health Act pending the outcome of psychiatric reports.

They also confirmed he had been sectioned under sections 48 and 49 of the Act, which allows health professionals to transfer someone from a prison to a hospital for assessment and treatment.

Tributes had previously been laid for the little boy who had been rushed to hospital after being discovered in the water

Little Zakari (above with mother Emma Blood) died after his father is alleged to have thrown him in the water

Under section 48 of the Act, prisoners can be transferred to a hospital while under section 49 they cannot be discharged from hospital unless the secretary of state says they can leave.

Well-wishers left flowers, soft toys and candles at the scene following Zakari's death.

Among the tributes was a large cuddly bear with a card that read: 'To a beautiful little boy. Sleep tight little man. Our thoughts are with your family. From all of us at Lidl Radcliffe.'

One card with flowers read: 'Goodnight and God Bless beautiful innocent boy. Fly high Angel.'
description: Zak Eko (pictured) is awaiting trial after being charged with murdering his son Zakari William Bennett-Eko in Manchester. He has been sectioned under the Mental Health Act.
